No. 7239] ALEXANDRIA, TUESDAY, JANUARY 3, 1905. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
PORT ARTHUR FALLS. SUUKENDER OF GARRISON HOSTILITIES SUSPENDED. SHIPS BLOWN UP TOKIO REJOICINGS. MIKADO’S TRIBUTE TO STOESSEL.
div.p: Tokio, January 2.
General Nogi reports that he has received a letter from General Stoessel relating to tho surrender of the fortress. Tho Japanese stormed and captured Wantai Fort yesterday.
(Reuter.)
Tokio, January 2.

It is understood that hostilities at Port Arthur are suspended to-day, and the Russian and Japanese Chiefs of the Staff are to meet at noon at Shunshiying, in order to discuss the question of the surrender.
General Stoessel has written to General Nogi saying that any further resistance is useless.
The Mikado has telegraphed to General Nogi extolling General Stoessel and ordering that all military honors be shown to him.
(Reuter.)
Tokio, January 1.
General Stoessel has proposed to General Nogi, and the latter has accepted, to negotiate the surrender of the place.
(Havas.)
Chi-Fu, January 2
General Stoessel wrote yesterday to General Nogi saying that all further resistance was useless and asked to capitulate.
The Russian and Japanese negotiators met at noon and separated at 4 o'clock.
The Russians accept the conditions proposed.
Hostilities are suspended.
The Russians blew up several forts and ships in the morning.
(Havas)
Tokio, January 2.
Immense rejoicings are taking place in the town.
(Reuter)
Tokio, January 2.
The capitulation of Port Arthur is causing great enthusiasm.
The Mikado has ordered homage to be paid to General Stoessel.
(Havas)
Tokio, January 2.

General Nogi informed General Stoessel that he agreed to appoint negotiators provided that the commissioners on both sides have full powers to sign an immediate capitulation. Meanwhile, hostilities have been suspended.
(Later). The negotiations lasted from noon until 4.30 p.m. Arrangements have been con- cluded to sign an act of capitulation. The Japanese terms have been accepted.
(Reuter.)

div.head: AWFUL CONDITION OP THE TOWN.
div.p: Chi-Fu, January 2.
(Midnight). The “Retvisan," the “Pol- tava,” and the “ Pallada " caught fire at Port Arthur in the morning; they were still burning during the afternoon. Tho Russians blew up the " Sevastopol.”

The Russian officers state there are 15,000 sick and wounded at Port Arthur. Many soldiers are lying in the streets, as the hospitals have been shattered by the shells. The garrison numbers 5,000, most of whom are convalescents.
(Reuter.)

div.head: RUSSIAN SHIPS AT CHI-FU.
div.p: Chi-Fu, January 2.

(Reuter.)
Chi-Fu, January 2.
Three large Japanese destroyers have entered the harbour.
(Reuter.)
Chi-Fu, January 2.
The Russian destroyers have disarmed, and the Japanese have consequently left the harbour.
(Reuter.)
Tsinqtau, January 2.
Two Russian destroyers and a merchantman with 800 soldiers have reached here.
(Reuter.)

div.head: OPINION ON THE PALL
div.p: London, January 2.

The concensus of opinion in diplomatic circles is that the fall of Port Arthur will only be a fresh incentive to renew the struggle more ' vigorously. Russia will not spare any efforts to recapture it, or compel its submission in- directly. The only reservation in this opinion is the internal condition of Russia, which is the dominant factor of the situation. (R.)

Amateur Theatricals.—The performance in Cairo of “The Pirates of Penzance” has been postponed, owing to the temporary absence of Lieut. Franklin, the musical director, in Khar- toum-. It will now probably take place about the third week in February. The respite is ap- preciated by the members of the troupe, as it was felt that the time allotted to the rehear- sals in the first instance was somewhat short. The delay will afford Major Delavoye more scope for the development of stage effects, and the performance will thus be as finished from a dramatic as from a musical point of view—a requirement not always sufficiently considered in the representation of comic operas by amateurs.

div.head: THE POSTMASTER GENERAL.
div.p: We are officially authorised to state that the announcement made to-day by a Cairo morning paper “on very good authority" that Saba Pa- sha, the Postmaster General, had tendered his resignation, is absolutely without any founda- tion whatsoever.

div.head: IMPORTANT APPOINTMENT.
div.p: We learn that Dr. W. St. C. Symmers, professor of pathology and bacteriology at the school of Medicine at Kasr-el-Aini, is about to leave Egypt to take up an important appointment in pathology at Belfast. Tbs Egyptian Government will feel the loss of a valuable servant, for Dr. Symmers, daring his sojourn in this country, has established for Himself a well-earned reputation as a scientific worker of great capacity and thoroughness. For his work at the Serum Institute for bovine typhus at Abbassieh the country owes him a special debt of gratitude. H.H. the Khedive has already testified his appreciation of Dr. Symmers' services in this connection by presenting him with a handsome set of diamond solitaires. Dr. Symmers' many friends in Egypt will boar of his approaching departure with regret.

div.head: ASSIOUT TRAINING COLLEGE.
div.p: The event of the Fall semester closing exercises of Assiout Training College was the contest between the Forum and Kiddonian Literary Societies. The representatives of the two societies, elected some months ago, contest- ed for honors in declamation, oration, and debate. The Kiddonian society won the oration and the debate, giving them five points out of six. The subjects of the two orations were “The Power of Oratory" and “Woman’s Power and Influence." 'The question for debate was “Resolved, that a final victory for Japan would be more beneficial to the world than a final victory for Russia.”

A feature of the occasion was the music, vocal and instrumental, furnished by local talent, assisted by Miss Dysart of Cairo. The singing of the college glee club was thoroughly enjoyed by all, and showed a great advance over anything the club has given in public heretofore.

A large number of the English-speaking community of Assiout were present,as the exercises were all in English. Every one was ready to congratulate the two societies and the college upon the great improvement in composition and style and delivery which was shown by the contest, since the orations and debate were entirely original productions by the students, with practically no changes made by the teachers. The two societies meet regularly each week, the results of careful drill and experience were quite manifest.

The college has enjoyed a very prosperous session, with an attendance of 550 students. A large new dining- room is being erected for the better accommodation of the boarding department. The staff of instructors now numbers twenty-three regular teachers, even of whom are Americans. A valuable addition to the corps was made this Fall, in the college savings secured Miss Strutters, recently of Boston, for instruction in art and penmanship, and Miss Moore, of Pennsylvania, as matron.

div.head: EGYPT’S TRADE.
NOVEMBER RETURNS.
div.p: The imports during the month kept up their usual rate of increase, which has been such a noticeable featereof this year’s customs returns. During November there was an increase of L.K. 794,898 over the figures for the cor- responding month lest year. Last November the imports amounted to L.E. 2,447,129, as against LE 1,653,231 in November, 1903. If December's imports showed a similar power of expansion the total imports for the year will show an increase of close upon L.R 4,000,000 over last year. Up to the end of November the imports amounted to L.R 18,140,838, as against L.R 15,038,399, an increase of LE. 8,107,439. The total exports during these eleven months amount to L.E. 18,201,952, an increase of L.R 1,705,341 over and above the figures for the corresponding period in 1903. The exports for November amounted to L.E. 8,666,967, a decrease of Li 884,857 on November lest year. This falling off is mainly to cotton exports, which decreased to value to the extent of LE 284,589, and cotton seed exports, which decreased by LE 76,482 com- pared with the figures for the previous November.

div.head: EGYPTIAN GOLD DEMAND.
div.p: The Statist understands that the Egyptian demand for gold is practically satisfied, which is entirely contrary to the general anticipa- tion. For some years past Egypt has been taking larger and larger amounts, and has been sending back less and less. It was gene- rally supposed that she would do the same this past year. As a matter of fact, she has taken exceptionally little.

The general explanation given is that Egyptian capitalists have been buying Egyp- tian bonds and Egyptian securities of all sorts in the London market upon a very large scale—upon so large a scale, in fact, that to all intents and purposes their purchases have counterbalanced the amount due to Egypt on account of her exports.

If the explanation be correct, it is interest- ing from two points of view: firstly, from the evidence it affords of the growth of wealth in Egypt. In all countries which have debts held in large amounts abroad, the natives begin to buy back those debts as soon as they advance in prosperity. Egypt, apparently, is doing this now. In the second place, it relieves the London market from one drain for gold. True, gold shipments after the turn of the year will not cause as much inconvenience as they would have caused during the past two or three months. Still it is well that the demand for the metal for abroad should decline.

div.head: THE TAWIL FAILURE
div.p: It has been decided to have a liquidation “a l'amiable” to the case of the failure of Mr. Selim TawiL Messrs. Gorrs, Sofio, and Deb- bane have been appointed liquidators.

It is estimated that the assets of Mr. Selim Tawil amount to LE 750,000 and the liabi- lities to LE 700,000. Even if this estimate is not correct it is thought that the liabilities will be sufficiently covered or even at the lowest estimate a dividend of 90 per cent, will be declared.

div.head: ZIZINIA THEATRE. “ADRIANA LECOUVREUR.”
div.p: There was a large house at the Zizinia on Saturday and again last night to witness the performance of Maestro Cilea’s new opera, which met with a huge success. Signs. Angelica Pandolfini's interpretation of the title role was one deserving of the highest commendation. Her singing and acting were imbued with a great degree of originality and intelligence, and her rendering of the death scene was admir- able. Signa. A. Pandolfinl was ably supported by Sig. Bravi, who mde an excellent Count de Saxe. Tho baritone Nani, in the role of Michonnet, also scored a distinct success. Sig. Galetti-Gianoli, as Prince de Bouillon, Signi. Sals, Foglia, and Rossini were also at their best. The "mise en scene” was as good as ever and the orchestra to fine form.

div.head: “STRIKE" AT THE VERDI DEPARTURE OF THE ARTISTES.
div.p: The strike of the artistes of the Verdi Theatre, Cairo, has terminated to a most un- satisfactory manner the majority of the com- pany having announced their determination to return to Italy as soon as possible and having refused to accept the modified terms offered by the management. In our opinion, they have had every reason to feel aggrieved at their treatment both by the direction and the Cairo public. The company was a vary strong one, containing artistes of really superior quality to any we have recently heard at the Khedivial Opera House, but none the less they failed almost entirely to attract the steady attendance of the music loving public. Certain performances drew large audiences, but in the main the results were disappointing to the extreme.

We attribute this to part to the want of sufficient advertisement, and to the methods of the ticket-office, which were not always as courteous as might be wished, but the blame lies mainly on the public, who were very ready to applaud a performance given last night for the benefit of the artistes who are leaving Egypt, bot never gave them that continued support which would have made their departure unnecessary. Last night's per- formance was very successful. It consisted of the 3rd act of Aida, which was excellently perform- ed, acts from Traviata and Trovatore, the Danza delle Ore from Gioconda, and the fourth act of Otello. The artistes were all at their best and we must again express our regret at the debacle so excellent a company.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL AGRICULTURAL SOCIETY
div.p: The following correspondence passed between the Minister of Finance and the President of the Khedivial Agricultural Society with regard to the new constitution of the latter;-

Sir,—Since the formation, to 1898, of the Khedivial Agricultural Society, in which the Government took an active part, the interest shown by all classes of the community to the agricultural development of the country has largely increased. The various measures adopt- ed by the society—such as the organization of shows, the distribution of seed and manure, and the publicity given to kindred subjects through the medium of the Society's journal- have given a stimulus to all matters relating to the cultivation of the soil. Egypt being essentially an agricultural country, the general welfare of the cultivator most always be an object of the utmost solicitude to the Govern- ment, which during recent years has continued to aid the Society both financially and otherwise.

From time to time, the desirability of creat- ing a Ministry of Agriculture has been urged, but the Government is of opinion that, for the present at all events, greater benefits will result from an extension of the work of the Society on certain lines. The principal defect in the past has lain to the fact that the central administration of the Society and the culti- vators were not in touch. In considering any new scheme of development, this point is one which should receive serious attention.

After a careful study of the existing Sta- tutes of the Society, the Government has drafted, for the consideration of members, s series of revised Statutes of which I have the honor to enclose a copy. This document will be found to indicate generally the changes which, in the opinion of the Government, it is advisable to introduce into the organization of the Society.

It is suggested that, to accordance with Article 21 of the present Statutes, a gene- ral meeting of members of the Society should be convoked, and that the proposed changes should be submitted to them for approval. Should the Statutes be adopted either to their entirety or with such modifications as the So- ciety may consider desirable and as the Go- vernment may approve, the Government is prepared to still further increase the annual subvention now granted to the Society, to order that they may be put into force.

It is proposed that the Moudirieh Delega- tions to which reference is made to Articles 13, 14 and 15 of the amended Statutes, should be substituted for those now existing in the Moudirieh towns of Gharbieh, Sharkia and Minia. Competent Secretaries for other Moudiriehs are not at present available, but as opportunities occur a gradual extension will be made to this direction, and the Govern- ment will, if necessary, consider the advisability of proportionately increasing the subvention. In the meantime, the society may engage students who have obtained their diplomas from the School of Agriculture: and these gentlemen, being placed on the Society’s experi- mental farms, and allowed to participate in the general work, will, in the course of a year or so, become competent to act as Secretaries to additional Moudirieh Delegations.

The extension thus given to the work of ths society will necessitate the appointment of an assistant to the present Secretary, as well as that of a paid Accountant in the office. To meet this increase of expenditure, as well as to provide for the three Moudirieh Delegations to which allusion is made above, the Govern- ment is prepared to grant a sum of LE 3,000 annually to addition to the subvention now accorded.

The question of the establishment of a Statistical bureau, for the collection of infor- motion relating to crop areas and general agricultural returns, to which the Society is greatly interested, is at present occupying the attention of the Government
The Government will be glad to learn in due course the result of tho deliberations or mem- bers, in order that the proposed changes, if adopted, may be put into force from January 1st, 1905.

I am to add that the Government would view with pleasure the election of Your High- ness as President of the Society and also of the Executive and General Committees ; of HH. Prince Ibrahim Pasha Hilmy and of H.E. Riaz Pasha as Vice-Presidents of the General Com- mittee ; of H.E. Chawarby Pasha and Mr. Gib- son as Vice-Presidents, and of Mr. Carey as Assistant Vice-President of the Executive Com- mittee. The Government would suggest the nomination of Mr. G. P. Fosden, the present Secretary of the society, as Secretary General
I have the honour to be, etc signed: Ahmed Mazloum, Minister of Finance.
(Translation).
Excellency,

I have the honour to acknowledge receipt of your letter No. 841, dated 23rd November, 1904, containing the changes which the Go- vernment deems advisable to introduce into the Administration of the Society. This letter, together with the proposed new Statutes of the Society which accompanied it, formed the subject of deliberation at a meeting of our General Committee held under my presidency on December 3rd last The changes proposed were received with great satisfaction by the Society, and the Statutes, with the exception of one or two minor changes which the society thinks will render them more perfect, and which, under cover and separate letter I have communicated to your Excellency for considera- tion by the Government, were unanimously adopted.

In accordance with the request contained to your Excellency’s letter, and in conformity with Art 21 of the existing Statutes of the Society, a general meeting of members was held on December 6th last at which the members cordially approved of the changes proposed and confirmed the decisions taken by the Com- mittee of the Society at its meeting of the 3rd inst. The society feels assured that the steps taken by the government to increase its sphere of usefulness will result in a much greater interest being taken in its work by agricultur- its generally. Through the medium of the proposed Moudirieh Delegations, the steps taken by the society to aid cultivators in a practical manner will receive greater publicity and the society feels assured that greater ad- vantage will be taken of them.

The members of the society view with great pleasure the continued interest which the Government takes in its work, and it is a great pleasure for me, as president of the society, to be the interpreter of the cordial votes and thanks which were passed at the meetings over which I had the honor to preside.
I have the honor to be, etc.
signed: Huessin Kamri, President.
His excellency, The Minister of Finance, Cairo.
